subcat.name: Alberta Liquor Licence
subcat.detail:
Overview

This dataset includes over seven thousands liquor service provider licensed by the Albertaa Gaming, Liquor & Cannabis (AGLC). AGLC regulates alcoholic beverages, recreational cannabis, and gaming-related activities. Each business is registered with establishment name, licensee name, authorization number, effective date, business address, licenses list, etc.

Dataset Information

Subject Business and Economy
Jurisdiction Province of Albertaa
Data Provider Albertaa Gaming, Liquor & Cannabis (AGLC)
Source aglc.ca
Attribution Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence - Albertaa.

Dataset Details

Liquor retailing, warehousing and distribution are all managed by the private liquor industry. Registered suppliers and agents are responsible for ordering, consolidating, shipping, and marketing liquor. AGLC is the legal importer of record for liquor in Albertaa. Manufacturers and suppliers sell liquor products to businesses (licensees) through AGLC. Licensees then sell liquor products to consumers.

AGLC administers and enforces the Gaming, Liquor and Cannabis Act (GLCA) and Regulation (GLCR). AGLC controls the importation, manufacture, sale, possession, storage, distribution, and use of liquor in Albertaa. AGLC also licences businesses in which liquor is sold or consumed.

AGLC adds a markup to the liquor it sells to liquor licensees. AGLC collects the markup on behalf of the government. The markup goes to the General Revenue Fund to support programs and initiatives that benefit all Albertaans. AGLC adds provincial markup, container deposit, recycling fees and all federal duties and taxes to the invoice price. This becomes the wholesale price. The Importation of Intoxicating Liquors Act (IILA) controls and restricts the movement of liquor from one province to another. It also controls liquor importation into Canada. The IILA gives provinces authority to control imports into their jurisdictions.

The following information are included: establishment name, licensee name, authorization number, effective date, business address, licenses list, etc.

The Province of Albertaa share with everyone its open and accessible datasets while adhering to rights of privacy, and publish datasets allowing everyone to develop digital applications that may improve government transparency and public participation, enhance access to City services, and ultimately strengthen democracy and contribute to a more liveable city. The city's Open Data Master Plan is a significant milestone and outlines a framework to guide the next phases of open data in the city towards the goal of using open data to improve service delivery and increase communication and data sharing between City divisions.

subcat.name: British Columbia Liquor Licence
subcat.detail:
Overview

This dataset includes over ten thousands liquor service providers licensed by the Liquor and Cannabis Regulation Branch (LCRB) of British Columbia. LCRB oversees the regulation and licensing of liquor and non-medical cannabis establishments and events. Each business is registered with establishment name, licensee name, licence number, expiry date, business address, etc.

Dataset Information

Subject Business and Economy
Jurisdiction Province of British Columbia
Data Provider The Liquor and Cannabis Regulation Branch (LCRB) of British Columbia
Source gov.bc.ca
Attribution Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence - British Columbia.

Dataset Details

The Liquor and Cannabis Regulation Branch (LCRB) oversees the regulation and licensing of liquor and non-medical cannabis establishments and events. A liquor licence or permit is required for selling liquor in B.C.

Liquor Primary licence are for businesses wanting to offer liquor as their primary focus or as an additional service to their patrons. Food Primary licence are for restaurants, bistros, cafes and other businesses where their primary focus is food. Manufacturer licence are for businesses producing or manufacturing liquor such as wine, cider, beer (including brew pubs), or spirits. Agent licence are for businesses that promote, market and take wholesale orders for liquor products. UBrew and UVin licence are for business that allow customers to ferment-on-premises. Catering licence are for businesses that cater food and beverages. Liquor Charitable Auction permit are for non-profits wanting to auction liquor at an event. Liquor Special Event Permit are for event hosts wanting to offer liquor service at special events. Ethyl Alcohol Purchase permit are for mechanical or manufacturing businesses wanting to use ethyl alcohol. Non-beverage Alcohol Exemption are for people who sell, supply, purchase or use non-beverage alcohol products. Rural Licensee Retail Store licence are for general stores to sell packaged liquor in rural communities and tourist destination resorts.

The following information are included: establishment name, licensee name, authorization number, expiry date, business address, licenses list, etc.

The Province of British_Columbia share with everyone its open and accessible datasets while adhering to rights of privacy, and publish datasets allowing everyone to develop digital applications that may improve government transparency and public participation, enhance access to City services, and ultimately strengthen democracy and contribute to a more liveable city. The city's Open Data Master Plan is a significant milestone and outlines a framework to guide the next phases of open data in the city towards the goal of using open data to improve service delivery and increase communication and data sharing between City divisions.

subcat.name: Montreal Food Establishments
subcat.detail:
Overview

This dataset includes over fifty thousands food establishments inspected the Food Inspection Division (Division de l'inspection des aliments) of the City of Montreal. The City is an agent of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food of Quebec (MAPAQ) with regard to inspections on its territory. Each business is registered with business number, business name, business type, location, status, and inspection violations, etc.

Dataset Information

Subject Health and Environment
Jurisdiction City of Montreal, Province of Quebec
Data Provider Montreal Food Inspection Division / Division de l'inspection des aliments de la Ville de Montréal
Source donnees.montreal.ca
Attribution Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence - Montreal.

Dataset Details

Food establishments located in Montreal are under the responsibility of the Food Inspection Division of the City of Montreal. This dataset contains all food establishments and those that have been convicted of an offense under the Act on food products (RSQ, c. P-29) and its regulations. During the inspection of a food establishment, if the inspector finds a violation of the regulations, a notice of violation is issued specifying the corrective measures to be taken. If the business refuses to comply, legal action is taken against the operator of the establishment, who is liable to a fine if found guilty.

The food inspection carried out by the City of Montréal by virtue of the powers delegated to it by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food of Quebec (Ministère de l'Agriculture, des Pêcheries et de l'Alimentation du Québec, MAPAQ). The food inspection mission is to ensure consumer protection by ensuring the safety and quality of food prepared, served and sold in food establishments in the restaurant, retail, processing, distribution and storage sectors. The inspection team inspects, based on health risks, food and activities related to the preparation, processing, storage and handling of food; advise food business operators, in order to promote good practices ensuring the safety of the foodstuffs consumed; carries out analyzes and expertise relating to the quality and safety of food.

Montréal believes that open data is a central element in achieving transparency and economic development objectives, but also in solving urban challenges. The more this data is made public and shared with the community, the more it will be exploited to its full potential in a booming Montreal ecosystem.

subcat.name: Montreal Commercial Properties
subcat.detail:
Overview

This dataset includes over twenty thousands commercial premises in Montreal. Each premise is intended for the practice of an economic activity (excluding industrial and institutional activities). Each property is registered with establishment name, property location, occupancy status, usages, etc.

Dataset Information

Subject Economy
Jurisdiction City of Montreal, Province of Quebec
Data Provider City of Montreal
Source donnees.montreal.ca
Attribution Contains information licensed under the Open Government Licence - Montreal.

Dataset Details

The field survey of commercial premises aims to develop a portrait of street commerce on the territory of Montreal in order to list the premises intended for the practice of an economic activity (excluding industrial and institutional activities). This dataset makes it possible to record the occupancy status of commercial premises, to monitor the evolution of street trading as well as to produce various analyzes and thematic maps.

The field survey of commercial premises 2022 took place between May and August 2022 on the entire territory of the agglomeration of Montreal. This survey was mainly aimed at premises with commercial signage visible from the street and located on the ground and second floors, as well as those located in the basement.

Montréal believes that open data is a central element in achieving transparency and economic development objectives, but also in solving urban challenges. The more this data is made public and shared with the community, the more it will be exploited to its full potential in a booming Montreal ecosystem.

subcat.name: Drug Product Database
subcat.detail:
Overview

This dataset includes 10 thousand drug products authorized for sale by Health Canada. Drugs can be identified by a Drug Identification Number (DIN), including drugs for humans and animals, disinfectants, radiopharmaceutical drugs, biological drugs for humans. Biological drugs for animals are regulated by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency. Each drug is disclosed with brand name, company name, business location, ingredients, classes, etc.

Dataset Information

Jurisdiction Federal
Data Provider Health Canada

Eight digit number assigned by Health Canada to a drug product prior to being marketed in Canada. It uniquely identifies all drug products sold in a dosage form in Canada and is located on the label of prescription and over-the-counter drug products that have been evaluated and authorized for sale in Canada. A DIN uniquely identifies the following product characteristics: manufacturer; product name; active ingredient(s); strength(s) of active ingredient(s); pharmaceutical form; and route of administration.
